Topic.Title: I HOPE WE OPEN AT 15 ON MONDAY

Message.Msg: My expectations are that the AIG suit will be in BAC and other's favor and that it will add another 25 cents to the price of BAC putting it just above $15 on a close. Whether that will happen Monday I don't know and I admit that some of that 25 cents may already be built into the current price. But the judge will probably hand down her decision next week. Then it may oscillate around $14.75 to $15.25 for the next few months before moving up again. Might even drop back down to the low $14s before September or October. But October should provide another good earnings report and then BAC should head towards $16 by the end of the year. That means I now expect BAC to reach $20 before the end of 2014. I am not sure when it will hit $20 during the next year. Could close around $22 by the end of next year if the dividend is raised. Just buy and don't sell is the safest strategy as the moves up will be sudden and unexpected. Selling on a down move could be the stupidest thing you could do.

Message.Title: Our company just announced much higher health care costs next year.
Message.Msg: I thought the new "affordable healthcare act" was supposed to be affordable and save me money. Our company just announced that healthcare cost inflation will be 50% higher next year due to "affordable" healthcare act. Employees that smoke have to pay much higher premiums than other employees starting next year, and spouses who work for companies that offer healthcare have to be removed from my company's healthcare coverage. If we lie and tell our company that spouse doesn't have healthcare, we get fired if they find out. The healthcare plan that my spouse's employer offers is awful, whereas I work for blue chip Fortune 50 company. My spouse had cancer last year, and her doctors aren't covered by her employer's healthcare plan. I have to decide whether to lie and say she doesn't have healthcare, or tell he to quit the job and lose $35,000 income. Any one else have same dilemma with their company?

Topic.Title: A single Democrat was responsible for bankrupting Orange County!

Message.Msg: Nobody is complaining about paying anyone a productive wage -- that's a strawman argument that you and everyone before you has invented out of thin air. But if, by that, you are referring to Republicans not supporting unions who want little more than to reduce productivity to increase the number of employees, bankrupt the company with silly work rules that require still more unproductive employees, and then go on strike when anyone threatens to touch the benefits that the union insists on and the company cannot afford, then I guess you are right. But I would argue that's not hypocrisy. It's common sense, but it's not hypocrisy. Hypocrisy is saying you want a living wage, then throwing in a luxury benefits/retirement package, then insisting on silly work rules that kill productivity and increase cost, then bankrupting your company, then complaining that Republicans are responsible for your job loss and your loss of benefits. Now THAT is hypocrisy.

You are wholly misinformed or mal-educated. Take your pick. Obamacare: Just Another Obama Failure
